natural problem:
Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$
natural solution: Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes sum :: real
assumes h0 : "sum = 1/(1*2) + 1/(2*3) + 1/(3*4) + 1/(4*5) + 1/(5*6)"
shows  "sum = 5/6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes sum :: real
assumes h0 : "sum = 1/(1*2) + 1/(2*3) + 1/(3*4) + 1/(4*5) + 1/(5*6)"
shows  "sum = 5/6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the sum of the following series: $\frac{1}{2*1} + \frac{1}{2*3} + \frac{1}{3*4} + \frac{1}{4*5} + \frac{1}{5*6}$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{6}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n \<in> {1..5}. f n = 1 / (n * (n + 1))"
shows  "sum f {1..5} = 5 / 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n \<in> {1..5}. f n = 1 / (n * (n + 1))"
shows  "sum f {1..5} = 5 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a function $f(n) = \frac{1}{n*(n+1)}$ for all natural numbers $n$ from 1 to 5, find the sum of $f(1)$, $f(2)$, ..., $f(5)$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{6}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: real
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "sum (\<lambda>i. 1 / (i * (i + 1))) {1..5} = 5 / 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. 1 / (i * (i + 1))) {1..5} = 5 / 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: real
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "sum (\<lambda>i. 1 / (i * (i + 1))) {1..5} = 5 / 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. 1 / (i * (i + 1))) {1..5} = 5 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Evaluate the sum of the series $\frac{1}{i*(i+1)}$ from $i=1$ to $5$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{6}$.

a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
shows  "1/(1*2) + 1/(2*3) + 1/(3*4) + 1/(4*5) + 1/(5*6) = (5::rat) / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Calculate the sum of the series $1/(1*2) + 1/(2*3) + 1/(3*4) + 1/(4*5) + 1/(5*6)$. The final answer is $5/6$.

a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 1/(1*2) + 1/(2*3) + 1/(3*4) + 1/(4*5) + 1/(5*6)"
shows  "x = 5/6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ where $x$ is the sum of the series $1/(1*2) + 1/(2*3) + 1/(3*4) + 1/(4*5) + 1/(5*6)$. The final answer is $5/6$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n / (n * (n + 1)) = 1/(n+1) - 1/n"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. 1/(n+1) - 1/n) {1..5} = 5/6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n / (n * (n + 1)) = 1/(n+1) - 1/n"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. 1/(n+1) - 1/n) {1..5} = 5/6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider the real number series where the nth term is given by the formula $1/(n+1) - 1/n$ for all $n > 0$. What is the sum of the first 5 terms in this series? The final answer is $5/6$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. sum n = 1 / (n * (n + 1))"
shows  "sum 1 + sum 2 + sum 3 + sum 4 + sum 5 = 5 / 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sum :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. sum n = 1 / (n * (n + 1))"
shows  "sum 1 + sum 2 + sum 3 + sum 4 + sum 5 = 5 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the sum of the series $1/(n*(n+1))$ for $n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5$. The final answer is $5/6$.

a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1..5}. 1 / (i * (i + 1))) = 5 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the sum of the series $\frac{1}{i*(i+1)}$ for $i$ from $1$ to $5$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{6}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n = 1 / (n * (n + 1))"
shows  "(\<Sum>n = 1..5. f n) = 5 / 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n = 1 / (n * (n + 1))"
shows  "(\<Sum>n = 1..5. f n) = 5 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Evaluate the sum of the function $f(n) = \frac{1}{n(n+1)}$ from $n = 1$ to $n = 5$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{6}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..5}. f n = 1 / (n * (n + 1))"
shows  "sum f {1..5} = 5 / 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express the following sum as a simple fraction in lowest terms.

$$\frac{1}{1\times2} + \frac{1}{2\times3} + \frac{1}{3\times4} + \frac{1}{4\times5} + \frac{1}{5\times6}$$ The final Answer is \frac{5}{6}
 ### Proof
 Any unit fraction whose denominator is the product of two consecutive numbers can be expressed as a difference of unit fractions as shown below. The second equation is the general rule. $$\frac{1}{99\times100} = \frac{1}{99} - \frac{1}{100}$$$$\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$$Each of the fractions in the given sum can be expressed as the difference of two unit fractions like so: $$\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6}\right)$$Observe that when the addition is performed, all terms but the first and last drop out.
 Therefore the sum is $1-\frac{1}{6}$ or $\boxed{\frac{5}{6}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..5}. f n = 1 / (n * (n + 1))"
shows  "sum f {1..5} = 5 / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ defined on natural numbers that maps each number $n$ in the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} to the real number $\frac{1}{n(n+1)}$. What is the sum of the function values of $f$ over this set? The final answer is $\frac{5}{6}$.
